Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation About a month ago, when youth resided at the facility, the youth
was in a physical altercation with another youth. A staff member
intervened, and body slammed the youth, choked the youth, and
scraped his nose. The youth has a scar from the incident.
2

Investigation Interviews:
Phone calls were made to Parent on December 3, 2024,
December 16, 2024, and December 30, 2024, none of which
were successful, and no return calls were received. In
addition, face-to-face contact was attempted at Parent house on
December 4, 2024, December 10, 2024, and January 7, 2025,
none of which were successful.
Youth A was unable to be interviewed as he is currently
AWOL and his whereabouts are unknown.
Youth B was unable to be interviewed as he is currently
AWOL and his whereabouts are unknown.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth D said he was placed at Clarence Fischer Center with Youth
A. Youth D said he had never seen Youth A being restrained.
Youth D said he heard about the fight between Youth A and Youth
B however he did not witness it occur. Youth D said after the fight
Youth A had a Band-Aid on his nose, but he is unsure why. Youth
D said the only other injury he is aware of with Youth A was his
broken hand from punching a wall. Youth D said he has never
seen Youth A or any other youth slammed to the ground or choked
by any staff.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth E said he was placed at Clarence Fischer Center with Youth
A for “about a month”. Youth E said he never witnessed Youth A
being restrained. Youth E said the only injury he is aware of with
Youth A was a “broken hand from fighting”, denying seeing any
scratches on Youth A’s face. Youth E said he has not seen or
heard of Youth A, or any other youth being slammed to the ground
or choked by any staff member.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth F said he was placed at Clarence Fischer Center with Youth
A. Youth F said he never saw Youth A get slammed to the ground
by any staff, however he reported he heard Youth B slammed
Youth A to the ground during a fight “in the fall”. Youth F said Youth
A never told him about any staff choking him. Youth F denied ever
seeing Youth A with any injury to his face or nose.
3

Youth G was unable to be interviewed as his whereabouts are
unknown. Youth G was discharged from Clarence Fischer Center
to Wayne County Juvenile Detention Center however is no longer
at that placement and his mother is not answering her phone or
returning phone calls to provide information on his whereabouts.
An attempted interview with Youth H face-to-face at the
facility occurred on December 17, 2024, in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. At that time Youth H stated he did not want to be
interviewed. A second successful interview occurred on January 7,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth H said he was
placed at Clarence Fischer Center with Youth A and remembers
the night of October 25, 2024. Youth H said he was outside talking
with Youth A, Youth G, and Youth I supervised by Lead Supervisor
and Supervisor Y. Youth H said it was dark outside, and they were
sitting under the basketball hoop in the parking lot. Youth H said
Youth B came outside and he, Youth A, and Youth G “jumped”
Youth B. Youth H said Supervisor Y and Staff 2 intervened to
break up the fight. Youth H said Staff 2 “grabbed [Youth A] by the
neck, picked him up, and slammed him on the concrete”. Youth H
said Youth A hurt his nose and scraped his knee as a result of this.
Youth H said Lead Supervisor pushed him to the ground and he
obtained “a large scrape on the back of his leg”. This is being
investigated in special investigation 2025SIC0000273. Youth H
said Staff 1 was also present, but she was not able to do anything
to help because she is “an older female” and “can’t deal with those
guys”. Youth H said he saw Staff 2 place Youth A in a “chokehold”
for a “few seconds” and afterwards Youth A told him he had been
unable to breathe. Youth H said he does not know if anyone else
saw the chokehold occur. Youth H said Youth I was asked by a
staff, he was unable to remember who, to “help” break up the fight
and she did. Youth H then said Youth I was also told not to be
involved and to go back to Vassar House, but she did not listen.
Youth I was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth I said she is currently placed at Vassar House however was
over at Clarence Fischer Center for “most of the day” on October
25, 2024. Youth I said she cannot recall which staff from Vassar
House was with her during the day but at night she was being
supervised by Supervisor Y until Supervisor Z came over to
Clarence Fischer Center. Youth I said she was sitting outside
talking with Youth A, Youth G, and Youth H when Youth B came
outside and began to “pick at scars” clarifying he was bringing up
“old stuff” with Youth A and Youth G, and then began to fight with
Youth A, Youth G, and Youth H. Youth I said Staff 2 held Youth H
4

back from the fight, however said it was not a restraint just holding
his arm. Youth I said all the staff were verbally redirecting Youth A,
Youth B and Youth G to stop fighting however they did not stop.
Youth I said Supervisor Y then “swung on [Youth A] and tackled
him to the ground.” Youth I said Youth A hit his head on the
ground. Youth I said Youth A was on his back and Supervisor Y
had his forearm across Youth A’s neck holding him down. Youth I
said Youth A “turned purple” for about “thirty seconds” and then
Supervisor Y let him go. Youth I said she does not know if Youth A
was having trouble breathing during the incident. Youth I said she
and Staff 1 “broke up the fight” between Youth B and Youth G.
Youth I said the fight lasted about two minutes and once it was
done, she assisted everyone with their injuries. Youth I said Youth
A had a “deep cut” on his nose and his nose appeared to be
“shifted to one side”. Youth I said she is unsure of how Youth A
obtained the cut on his nose, stating she did not believe it was
from being brought to the ground by Supervisor Y as he was on
his back not his stomach. Youth I said the police and ambulance
came due to the fight and she was unsure if any youth were sent
to the hospital. Youth I said Lead Supervisor was not present that
night. Youth I said she does not know if Staff 1 or Staff 2 saw
Youth A being tackled to the ground by Supervisor Y.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on December 19, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 said she has been
employed at Clarence Fischer Center since July of 2024, and is a
third shift youth specialist. Staff 1 said she arrived to work on
October 25, 2024, and Supervisor Y, Staff 2, and Lead Staff were
outside with Youth A, Youth B, Youth G, Youth H and Youth I. Staff
1 said as she approached the group, Youth A, Youth G, Youth H,
all “jumped” Youth B. Staff 1 said Supervisor Y and Staff 2
immediately started to intervene to stop the fight. Staff 1 said
Supervisor Y removed Youth A in a proper hold and then was
dealing with Youth A behind her back. Staff 1 said Lead Supervisor
had gotten Youth H to the side, and she was focused on helping
Staff 2 get Youth B and Youth G off from each other. Staff 1 said
Youth I was trying to help her and Staff 2 stop Youth B and Youth
G from fighting, and she redirected Youth I to stop and get back
however she did not listen. Staff 1 said as they were trying to stop
Youth B and Youth G they all were moving around and at one
point she remembered seeing Supervisor Y and Youth A on the
ground, however she said she did not see how they got to the
ground. Staff 1 said Supervisor Y had Youth A’s arms and was
sitting next to him. Staff 1 denied seeing Supervisor Y have any
part of his body near Youth A’s neck. Staff 1 said once the fight
ended, she went with Youth G inside as he had hit his head on the
5

ground and was “out of it”. Staff 1 said she does not recall Youth A
ever yelling out in pain or that he was unable to breath, however
said it was a very chaotic situation. Staff 1 said she does not recall
any injury to Youth A’s face. Staff 1 said Supervisor Y seems really
good with the youth and she has never seen him act
inappropriately with the youth. Staff 1 said Lead Supervisor was
close by the fight standing next to Youth H and should have been
able to see the entire incident. Staff 1 said Lead Supervisor was
on restrictions and therefore unable to intervene with the youth
that were fighting.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on December 19, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said he is currently
a youth care specialist working third shift and has worked for
Wolverine Human Services on and off since 2016. Staff 2 said he
was working on October 25, 2024, when the fight occurred with
Youth A, Youth B, Youth G, and Youth H. Staff 2 said Supervisor Y,
Lead Supervisor, and Staff 1 were also working and present
during the incident. Staff 2 said around 10pm he was arriving to
work and Youth A, Youth B, Youth G, Youth H, and Youth I were
outside with Lead Supervisor, Supervisor Y, and Staff 1. Staff 2
said he does not recall how it started however remembers Youth
A, Youth G, and Youth H “jumped” Youth B. Staff 2 said he and
Supervisor Y began to try to separate Youth A, Youth B, and Youth
G, while Youth H was removed from the area by Lead Supervisor.
Staff 2 said Supervisor Y “got [Youth A] away from the fight”
however said he does not recall seeing Supervisor Y take Youth A
to the ground but does remember Youth A telling him afterwards
that Supervisor Y took him to the ground. Staff 2 said he was
focused on separating Youth B and Youth G and was able to get
his body in-between the two youth and they stopped fighting. Staff
2 said Staff 1 and Youth I were also trying to help break up the
fight between Youth A, Youth B, and Youth G. Staff 2 said he never
asked Youth I to help intervene in the fight, however also stated he
was focused on Youth B and Youth G so never told her to stop
either. Staff 2 said Youth G appeared “dazed” after the fight and
Staff 1 took him inside while he followed Youth B over to where
Lead Supervisor was standing with Youth H. Staff 2 said Youth B
acted like he was going to start fighting with Youth H and Lead
Supervisor stood in front of Youth H so Youth B could not get to
him. Staff 2 said he then took Youth B inside to talk to him. Staff 2
said Lead Supervisor should have been able to see everything
that occurred during the incident from where he was standing with
Youth H. Staff 2 denied seeing Supervisor Y hit, choke, or tackle
Youth A. Staff 2 said Youth A had “knicks and bruises” after the
6

fight and recalls some scratches on his face however unsure if
they were on his nose or not.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Z said she is currently a supervisor at Clarence
Fischer Center and was working on October 25, 2024. Supervisor
Z said she was at Vassar House and went over to Clarence
Fischer Center for third shift on October 25, 2024. Supervisor Z
said when she arrived Youth A was sitting in a chair waiting to be
“sent out” for medical attention due to scratches on his arm and
issues with his hand. Supervisor Z denied seeing any injury to
Youth A’s face or neck at that time, noting she did not spend a lot
of time with him as she went to a unit where Youth B was and
helped deescalate him. Supervisor Z said she did not see the fight
between the youth or the restraint with Supervisor Y and Youth A.
Supervisor Z said Youth A never talked to her about any concerns
with Supervisor Y’s restraint.
Supervisor Y was interviewed via telephone on December 17,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor Y said
he has been a supervisor for about eleven months and is currently
on medical leave. Supervisor Y said he remembers the incident on
October 25, 2024, as he was the acting third shift supervisor that
night. Supervisor Y said Youth A, Youth G, and Youth H “jumped”
Youth B in the parking lot by Clarence Fischer Center’s basketball
hoop. Supervisor Y initially said he restrained Youth A for assisting
the other youth in “jumping” Youth B. Supervisor Y later described
the incident stating he “tackled him [Youth A] to the ground and
laid on him to stop him”. When Supervisor Y was asked some
clarifying questions about the maneuvers used to “tackle” Youth A
he described the incident saying, he “used a little force” as Youth A
was hitting Youth B, he “tipped him over and laid on him with my
arms over his body” stating Youth A was “on his stomach” until
Youth A was “calm” which was “about five or six minutes”.
Supervisor Y said Lead Supervisor was present and witnessed the
entire event and never told him what he was doing was incorrect
or inappropriate and never discussed the incident with him
afterwards. Supervisor Y said Staff 2 was also present for the
incident however was separating and “dealing with” Youth B and
Youth G, so he was unsure if he saw him and Youth A on the
ground. Supervisor Y said Youth H was outside and standing near
Lead Supervisor, Youth G was fighting Youth B, and Youth I was
present from Vassar House and was trying to assist Staff 2 in
“breaking up the fight” between Youth B and Youth G. Supervisor
Y clarified that prior to the fight he had been supervising Youth I
7

until her staff came from Vassar House to get her. Supervisor Y
said after the fight, Youth A was scratched up but he did not
remember seeing any injury to his nose. Supervisor Y stated
everyone was scratched up, including staff from the incident.
Supervisor Y denied ever choking Youth A when laying on him.
Supervisor Y said they are not trained for an incident like that,
stating he was “doing his best” to stop Youth A from “beating the
hell out of [Youth B]”. Supervisor Y said he felt he needed to stop
Youth A as he was the “biggest kid” and that would help control the
situation.
Lead Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face two different
times on December 17, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS. An
additional face-to-face interview was completed on January 14,
2025, with Lead Supervisor. During each interview, Lead
Supervisor said he has no memory of the incident on October 25,
2024. Lead Supervisor said he has no memory of Youth A ever
having an injury on his nose, stating the only injury he recalls with
Youth A was his hand injury from a different incident. Lead
Supervisor denied ever seeing Youth A being slammed to the
ground by Supervisor Y or any other staff at any time. Lead
Supervisor said he has not had any issues or concerns with
Supervisor Y, reporting he seems like a “creditable” person.
Documents Reviewed:
• Supervisor Y’s personnel file: Supervisor Y had disciplinary
action on July 10, 2024, for violating the clear drink policy;
on September 19, 2024, for leaving his shift early; on
September 26, 2024, for not completing his paperwork; on
September 29, 2024, for arriving late to work however
documenting he was on time; and on October 31, 2024, for
failure to follow medication passing procedures.
• Youth A’s medical documents from McLaren Caro
Community Hospital dated October 26, 2024. The medical
documents do not report any cuts or scratches on Youth
A’s face, however, did report “a fracture at the base of the
fifth metacarpal” from a “fight” the “night prior”.
• Wolverine Human Services Behavior Support and
Management Policy was reviewed. The approved
techniques for staff to utilize during a physical restraint do
not include a ground or floor hold.
• MiSACWIS Incident Report 198750239 dated October 25,
2024, for Youth A. The incident report is not consistent with
any staff interviews. The incident states “On 10/25/24 at
11:37 PM [Youth A] was sitting outside with clients by CFC
when he was approached by peer [Youth B]. [Youth A] and
8

his peer began to argue and then a fight broke out between
the two. Staff managed the environment and protective
intervention to break up the fight. [Youth A] later
complained that his right hand was swollen and he was
sent to McLaren ER for evaluation, had x-rays, completed
and returned to site.”
• The Wolverine Human Services Incident Report dated
October 25, 2024, was reviewed. The incident report
stated, “No Restraint Used” and “Staff were able to break
up the fight and keep [Youth A] and his peer apart”.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per Supervisor Y’s
interview he admitted to taking Youth A to the ground on his
stomach and then laying on him for approximately five to six
minutes, in order to stop the youth from fighting and manage the
environment.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
